discovery_instructions: Identify what the main item/entity is for this feature (e.g., ticket, workflow, employee, record)
Look for list/table views - the rows represent the primary entity
Check page headers and breadcrumbs for entity naming
Note the singular and plural forms used in the UI

find_trigger: Look for buttons with: + Add, + Create, + New, plus icon
Check top-right corner of the page
Look in empty state messages for create prompts
create.validation: New item appears in list with unique identifier

find_trigger: Click on any row in a list/table
Look for 'View' or eye icon buttons
Check if rows are clickable (cursor changes)
read.validation: Detail panel, modal, or page opens showing full information

find_trigger: Look for Edit button, pencil icon
Check for inline editing (click on field to edit)
Look for status change dropdowns or buttons
Check action menus (three-dot menu) for edit option
update.validation: Changes persist after save, reflected in list view

find_trigger: Look for Delete button, trash icon
Check action menus (three-dot menu) for delete option
Look for bulk delete with checkboxes
Some features use 'Archive' or 'Cancel' instead of delete
delete.validation: Item removed from list or status changed to deleted/archived

Document any modals, dialogs, slide-out panels
Identify form fields and input types when forms appear
Look for filters, search, sort, and export options
Check for bulk action controls (checkboxes, select all)
Note any settings or configuration options

what_to_do.task: Configure and manage biometric attendance devices and data integration within the Bayzat platform.
steps: Manually add biometric devices with required details such as serial number and office assignment (TSSD-2792).
Ensure biometric device logs are properly synchronized and processed by the platform, noting limitations on data volume and timing (TSSD-4710, TSSD-2381).
Use the attendance module to track biometric check-ins and check-outs, understanding that location validation may have limitations (TSSD-3737, TSSD-3180).
Monitor attendance data and reports, noting that some custom reports may not include office location details for API-based attendance (TSSD-4151).
Be aware of the facial recognition check-in process and its retry limits, including error handling and user experience considerations (OS-3136, OS-3137).
Understand the limitations in fraud detection reporting when device IDs are missing (TSSD-287).
Use available reporting tools like Looker for biometric device data, recognizing the lack of centralized automated reporting (TSSD-4269).
what_to_do.expected_outcome: Biometric attendance devices are configured and integrated, attendance data is accurately captured and synchronized within platform constraints, and users can track attendance with awareness of current system limitations.

what_to_watch_out_for.issue: Data synchronization and integration challenges with biometric devices and attendance logs.
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The platform struggles with high-volume biometric log ingestion, lacks full location validation during check-ins, and has a limited one-week window for processing biometric data. Facial recognition lacks robust error handling and image validation, and fraud detection is limited when device IDs are null.
what_to_watch_out_for.workaround: Manual monitoring and intervention may be required for large data volumes and error cases. Users must manually configure devices and be aware of policy enforcement inconsistencies. Use dropdowns for employee selection in mass uploads to maintain data integrity.

what_to_watch_out_for.issue: Limited API and documentation support for biometric attendance integration.
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: API integration does not support passing office location details, and biometric API documentation may be outdated or unclear.
what_to_watch_out_for.workaround: Refer to the most recent platform updates and manual configuration steps; developer involvement may be necessary for complex integrations.

what_to_watch_out_for.issue: User experience and security gaps in facial recognition and biometric consent management.
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: Facial recognition retry limits and failure screens lack consistent handling; no standardized consent tracking for biometric features; facial recognition can accept blank images, posing security risks.
what_to_watch_out_for.workaround: Users should be informed of retry limits and error states; manual consent management may be needed; security risks require attention from development teams.

what_to_watch_out_for.issue: Feature and reporting limitations in biometric attendance data management.
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: Mass upload workflows restrict direct Employee ID input; no centralized automated reporting for biometric devices; future timestamped biometric data cannot be rendered in UI.
what_to_watch_out_for.workaround: Use dropdown selections for employee identification; manually access Looker reports; be aware of UI rendering limitations.

what_to_watch_out_for.issue: Integration complexity and device compatibility challenges.
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: Different biometric devices require different integration methods; not all devices are seamlessly supported; manual configuration is necessary.
what_to_watch_out_for.workaround: Technical resources and developer involvement may be required; verify device compatibility before integration.
